children.alt: Mean nearest neighbor distances for the four examples.

children.value: Mean nearest neighbor distances for the four examples.
Area size has to match the study area
Area size will affect the distance between points.
The number of points has to match the dataset
Within the same area, more points (higher density) will lead to lower nearest neighbor distances.

children.alt: Monte Carlo Simulation for point pattern.

children.value: Monte Carlo Simulation for point pattern.
After simulating random for M times, we will get

children.html: MMM

children.value: measurement of mean nearest neighbor distances.
The frequency distribution of the N values would form a normal distribution.
The range where the normal distribution is located represent the “random (CSR)” under the specific area and # point setting.

children.alt: Normal distribution pattern for the frequency of the NNA statistics for the simulated pattern.

children.value: Normal distribution pattern for the frequency of the NNA statistics for the simulated pattern.
, we found a clear evidence that the observed pattern is different from random.

, then, we did not find any evidence to prove that the observed pattern is different from random.

(3) If the observed fall at the edge of the normal distribution
p-value: the probability of being wrong to reject null hypothesis
See [ESRI “What is a z-score? What is a p-value?”(

children.alt: If the oberved value fall within or near to the edge of the normal bell shape.

children.value: If the oberved value fall within or near to the edge of the normal bell shape.

Let’s say we set the confidence level to 99%, meaning we are willing to accept a 1% risk of being wrong (incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis, H0).
If the obtained p-value is 3%, which is higher than our acceptable risk, then we cannot reject H0.

children.alt: How the observed mean compared with 10k CSR simulations mean results?

children.value: How the observed mean compared with 10k CSR simulations mean results?
The grey area indicates the mean nearest neighbor distance of the 10k random pattern.
Z-test is another option for testing the significant levels of how observed nearest neighbor distance (

children.html: DˉO\bar{D}_ODˉO​

children.value: ) is different from the ‘expected’ average nearest neighbor distance (

children.html: DˉE\bar{D}_EDˉE​
ANN=DˉODˉE\text{ANN} = \frac{\bar{D}_O}{\bar{D}_E}ANN=DˉE​DˉO​​
ANN\text{ANN}ANN

children.value:
) is less than 1, the pattern exhibits clustering.
If the index is greater than 1, the trend is toward dispersion.
The expected mean distance could be calculated using the number of point (n) and the study area (A):

children.html: DˉE=0.5n/A\bar{D}_E = \frac{0.5}{\sqrt{n/A}}DˉE​=n/A​0.5​

children.value: The z-score can then be calculated using

children.html: DˉO\bar{D}_ODˉO​
DˉE\bar{D}_EDˉE​
z=DˉO−DˉESEz = \frac{\bar{D}_O - \bar{D}_E}{SE}z=SEDˉO​−DˉE​​

children.value: The z-score and p-value for this statistic are sensitive to changes in the study area or changes to the Area parameter. For this reason, only compare z-score and p-value results from this statistic when the study area is fixed.

children.alt: Z-test and z-score. See ESRI “What is a z-score? What is a p-value?” for more details.

children.value: ESRI “What is a z-score? What is a p-value?”
This approach calculates the average distance of the nearest neighbor for every point.
The observed average nearest neighbor distance can be tested using a Monte Carlo Simulation or z-test approaches against the null hypothesis of CSR.
The NNA has an assumption that the points being measured are
free to locate anywhere within the study area
(for example, there are no barriers, and all cases or features are located independently of one another).
